analysis_categories.name: physicalCharacteristics
analysis_categories.description: Visual assessment of product dimensions, materials, and build quality
questions: What are the visible dimensions and proportions relative to common objects in the images?
What materials and finishes are identifiable from close-up shots?
Are there any visible quality indicators in the construction or assembly?

analysis_categories.name: usageContext
analysis_categories.description: Understanding how and where the product is used
questions: What environmental context is shown in product usage photos?
How does the product interact with or fit into its intended space?
What complementary items or accessories are shown being used with the product?

analysis_categories.name: designDetails
analysis_categories.description: Specific design elements and features visible in images
questions: What control interfaces or adjustment mechanisms are visible?
How are different components arranged or connected?
What design choices are evident in the product's aesthetics?

analysis_categories.name: qualityIndicators
analysis_categories.description: Visual cues that suggest product quality or durability
questions: Are there visible manufacturing details that suggest quality level?
Do seams, joints, or connection points appear robust?
Are there any visible quality concerns in finish or materials?

analysis_categories.name: userInteraction
analysis_categories.description: How users physically interact with the product
questions: How is the product held, manipulated, or operated in usage images?
What ergonomic features are visible in the design?
Are there visible accessibility considerations in the interface design?

elements: Compare to standard objects in frame
Identify all visible controls and interfaces
Note accessibility of common adjustment points
Inventory all visible accessories and parts
Identify any missing but expected components

implementation_guidance: Always cross-reference image observations with provided specifications
Use image analysis to verify or challenge written claims
Document any discrepancies between images and product descriptions
Look for unintentional revelations in background or context of images
Consider both official product photos and customer-submitted images
red_flags_checklist: Missing or obscured important product features
Artificially enhanced or modified product appearance
Lack of detail in critical areas

dimension_estimation_techniques.description: Methods for making accurate size and proportion assessments from images

techniques.name: referenceObjectComparison
techniques.description: Using common objects in frame to estimate size
implementation: Identify common objects with known dimensions (coins, credit cards, phones)
Compare product dimensions relative to reference objects
Calculate approximate measurements based on known reference dimensions
techniques.example: The device appears approximately 2.5 credit cards in width, suggesting a dimension of roughly 3.75 inches.

techniques.name: humanHandScaling
techniques.description: Using human hands in images to gauge product size
implementation: Note how the product is held or manipulated by hands
Compare to average hand dimensions (adult palm width ~3.5 inches)
Assess whether product appears small, medium, or large in relation to typical hands
techniques.example: The device is completely obscured within an average adult palm, indicating a compact size of 3 inches or less.

techniques.name: environmentalContextAnalysis
techniques.description: Using surrounding environment to estimate size
implementation: Identify standard fixtures or furniture in images (countertops, desk surfaces)
Note how much space product occupies in standard environments
Compare to typical dimensions of environmental elements
techniques.example: The appliance occupies approximately 1/4 of a standard countertop depth, suggesting a depth of 6-7 inches.

accuracy_guidelines: Express estimates as ranges rather than precise measurements
Use multiple estimation techniques and cross-reference results
Note confidence level in estimations (high, medium, low)
Always seek confirmation of critical dimensions from specifications

material_identification_framework.description: System for identifying and assessing materials from visual cues

visual_cues: Visible machining patterns or brushed finishes
quality_assessment: Precision of machined edges and corners
Uniformity of color and surface treatment

visual_cues: Visible seams or injection molding lines
quality_assessment: Absence of flash or excess material at edges

implementation_guidance: Look for material transitions and joints to identify different components
Pay particular attention to high-stress areas for quality assessment
Note when materials don't match across similar components
Consider functional appropriateness of identified materials

user_interface_analysis.description: Framework for evaluating visible interface elements from images

assessment_criteria: Size and spacing appropriate for target users
Screen size relative to information density
Intuitive use of colors or symbols
Clarity of port labeling or identification

usability_inference_guidelines: Note whether controls appear to require one or two hands
Assess whether text/icons would be visible to users with visual impairments
Consider whether interface could be operated without looking directly at it
Evaluate if interface appears intimidating or welcoming to new users

contextual_usage_analysis.description: Framework for extracting usage insights from contextual images

analysis_focus: Lighting conditions shown in usage scenarios
Apparent age ranges of users in imagery
Physical capabilities implied by usage postures
Family or group usage vs. individual use
Types of activities product is shown supporting

implementation_guidance: Consider whether shown contexts match likely real-world usage
Note any obvious omissions in contextual representation
Identify any specialized environment requirements implied by images
Consider whether product appears versatile across different contexts

image_integration.description: Framework for effectively incorporating and referencing images in review content

reference_principles.name: specificity
reference_principles.description: Direct references to visual details in images
examples: As shown in image 2, the textured grip pattern extends 3 inches along the handle
Note the size comparison with a quarter in image 1 for scale

reference_principles.name: contextEnhancement
reference_principles.description: Use images to strengthen written points
examples: The slight discoloration visible in image 3 demonstrates the wear pattern
Image 4 highlights the seamless connection points discussed above

actions: Identify key visual elements requiring documentation
Plan image sequence to support review flow
List specific details to highlight in each image
Reference images near relevant text sections

comparative_visual_analysis.description: Framework for comparing product appearance with competitors or alternatives

analysis_focus: Different form factor approaches to similar functions
Simplicity vs. complexity in interface design
Learning curve implications of different interfaces

implementation_guidance: Note both objective and subjective differences
Consider different user priorities when assessing differences
Avoid purely aesthetic judgments without functional context
